text: What do you know about the exterior angles of a polygon? How might this knowledge be useful?

Exterior angles are the supplement of interior angles. Knowing that the sum of the two angles is 180˚ can help us solve problems about the angles on a polygon.

The sum of the interior angles of polygons changes depending on the numbers of sides. The sum of the exterior angles of any polygon is always 360˚

Did You Know?

Five smart things honeybees can do. The following comments come from:

https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/feb/10/five-smart-things-honeybees-can-do

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3629984/

These insects’ brains are tiny, but they know numbers and communication.

Crunch numbers

Scientists found that honeybees can learn to add and subtract. Fourteen bees were put through 100 training exercises. They were correct 64% – 72% of the time. “It is not that every bee could do this, but we could teach them to do it,” said Dr. Adrian Dyer, research co-author.

Solve tasks

In 2017, researchers from Queen Mary University of London demonstrated that bees can learn to gain a reward and then show others to do the same. The bees were taught by a decoy bee to move a small ball to a particular location – and some of them even managed to solve the task more efficiently by shortening the distance.

Give directions

Karl von Frisch was awarded the 1973 Nobel Prize for decoding the “waggle dance” performed by bees to tell hive-mates the location of food sources. A bee vibrates its wings to relay information about the location of food in relation to the position of the sun.

Understand zero

Honeybees were the first insect species to be observed to have a concept of zero, a numerical idea that many find difficult to learn. Researchers at RMIT University in Melbourne showed that bees conceive zero as a number, but they were unclear why they had this skill.

Share decisions

Bees have a sense of democracy. When looking for a new home for, say 10,000 bees, 300 older bees form a “senate” and fly off looking for options. Using the waggle dance, they communicate possible locations. The number of dance repetitions tells the quality of the site.
